questions.text: True regarding the presentation of primary T.B. is: Which of the following is most likely in a young European child visiting India for the first time and coming in contact with a patient with active pulmonary tuberculosis?

options.label: A
options.text: B/L pleural effusion with negative Tuberculin test

options.label: D
options.text: B/L pleural effusion with positive tuberculin test

questions.explanation:
Solution:

U/L hilar lymphadenopathy Primary TB:- It usually occurs in childhood, and the lungs are the most frequent site of initial contact with the tubercle bacilli. Transmission of TB is via inhalation. Primary Focus: - (also known as Gohn focus) Almost always found just beneath the pleura in the basal segment of the upper lobe or apical part of the lower lobe. (where there is the most significant volume of inspired air.) The focus is usually tiny (< 1cm). Microscopically, typical caseating granulomas are seen. Organisms drain to hilar nodes, again with the formation of granulomas . Primary (Ghon) Complex = Primary focus + involvement of regional lymph nodes in primary TB. Primary foci are usually entirely asymptomatic. The old sites of the healed primary TB infection may be marked by a pulmonary nodule or granuloma in the lung, which may become calcified over time. These nodules are known as "Ghon lesions." The finding is called " Ranke's complex " when seen together with ipsilateral calcified hilar adenopathy; the result is termed a “Ranke’s complex.” Apical scarring with the appearance of a fibronodular patch or ill-defined reticular shadow in the upper lung fields on chest x-ray is known as "Simon's focus, " and in a patient with a positive tuberculin skin test identifies a patient with a markedly increased risk for active TB. Rich Focus - tuberculous caseous foci in the brain, meninges, and spinal cord

questions.text: Chronic interstitial pulmonary diseases are a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized predominantly by inflammation and fibrosis of the lung interstitium. The most common of them is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. The most common histologic pattern of this type of ILD is unique interstitial pneumonia (UIP). Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with UIP?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Subpleural sparing The typical finding associated with UIP (advanced) includes the following - Loss of lung architecture Option: D-Subpleural and basal reticular changes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Traction bronchiectasis Option: B. Honeycombing Option: C. Bilateral reticular infiltrates Lungs are cobblestoned due to the retraction of scars along the interlobular septa. The cut surface shows firm, rubbery white areas of fibrosis, which occurs preferentially in the lower lobes, subpleural regions, and interlobular septa. Microscopically, the hallmark is patchy interstitial fibrosis. Cobblestone lungs can be seen in ILD as the end stage of lung damage. Subpleural sparing is a feature of nonspecific interstitial pneumonia.

5-year survival < 50%

Highyeild:

Features of NSIP - Ground glass opacities (Option: 1) No cysts No honeycombing No traction bronchiectasis No loss of lung parenchyma architecture Positive serologic tests for connective tissue disease are frequently observed. Idiopathic NSIP has a relatively good prognosis (Option: 2), with a 5-year survival >80% . Whereas for UIP, the 5-year survival rate is <50%. questions.text: Remodeling of the interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium, tends to be the dominant site of involvement for most interstitial lung diseases (ILDs); keeping this in mind, which of the following is not expected to be a part of interstitial lung diseases?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bronchiectasis Bronchiectasis is an obstructive disease. It is a disorder where the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by inflammation stemming from persistent or severe infections leads to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles. In bronchiectasis, airways like bronchi get dilated till the lung's periphery. It is not associated with any defect between the alveolar epithelium and endothelium of vessels. Therefore , it can not be clubbed as interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient diagnosed with diffuse systemic sclerosis presented to opd for dyspnea on exertion. The pulmonary function test was - FEV1/FVC = normal FVC = reduced DLCO = decreased What is the correct pathogenesis of the lung condition in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Remodelling of the region between alveolar epithelium and endothelium of vessels

options.label: B
options.text: Angioproliferative vasculopathy in the pulmonary arterioles leads to endothelial and smooth muscle proliferation, dysfunction, inflammation, and thrombosis

options.label: C
options.text: Reversible airflow obstruction and abnormal inflammatory response in the lungs

options.label: D
options.text: Focus of atypical epithelial cells within the bronchial mucosa

questions.correct_answer: A. Remodelling of the region between alveolar epithelium and endothelium of vessels
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Remodelling of the region between alveolar epithelium and endothelium of vessels. The most common lung condition in diffuse systemic sclerosis is interstitial lung disease. It is associated with decreased diffusion capacity and restrictive patterns on DLCO. The pulmonary function test also points towards a restrictive pathology. So the lung condition can be streamlined as ILD. The pathogenesis represents - interstitial lung disease where there is remodeling of the region between the alveolar epithelium and endothelium of vessels.

The blood tests revealed positive rheumatoid factor, CCP antibodies, elevated ESR, and C-reactive protein. He has a 54-pack-year history of smoking. questions.explanation:

Unique interstitial pneumonia Morning stiffness with positive rheumatoid factor, CCP antibodies, elevated ESR, and C-reactive protein point towards the diagnosis of Rheumatic Arthritis. A common extraarticular complication of RA is Although RA is more common in females, RA-ILD is more frequent in males and patients with a history of tobacco exposure. In a small subset of patients, ILD is the first disease manifestation of RA. Clinically evident RA-ILD occurs in nearly 10% of the RA population; however, up to 40–50% of subjects have radiologic abnormalities on chest CT suggesting ILD in the context of RA may be under-diagnosed. The most common imaging pattern of ILD in patients with RA is a UIP pattern , although NSIP patterns are not uncommon. questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient presented to medicine OPD with dyspnea on exertion. A pulmonary function test revealed restrictive pathology, and ILD was suspected. Radiological imaging was advised. Which of the following imaging can assist in the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above ILDs can be identified incidentally based on the results of abnormal pulmonary function tests , chest x-rays (CXRs), computed tomography (CT) studies of both the chest and abdomen (which can both visualize, at least a portion, of the lung parenchyma), and positron emission tomography (PET) scans. All of these investigations are very helpful in localizing the lesion accurately and its further management.
